summary: This document is an email chain from September 2008 regarding a request for a written staff opinion from the Florida Bar's ethics counsel. An Assistant U.S. Attorney from West Palm Beach forwards an inquiry and attachments related to victim notification procedures, likely in connection with the Epstein case.

persons.name: Elizabeth Clark Tarbert
persons.context: She is the ethics counsel at the Florida Bar who is responding to an inquiry about a written staff opinion, noting a typical 3-5 week reply time.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: An unnamed Assistant U.S. Attorney from West Palm Beach, Florida, is forwarding an earlier email and attachments to request a written staff opinion from the Florida Bar's ethics counsel.

connections.description: The Assistant U.S. Attorney is requesting a written staff opinion from Elizabeth Clark Tarbert, the ethics counsel, regarding an unspecified matter, likely related to victim notification in a case.

events.title: Email request for ethics opinion
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney forwards an inquiry and attachments to the Florida Bar's ethics counsel, Elizabeth Clark Tarbert, requesting a written staff opinion.

events.title: Initial request for written staff opinion
events.description: The Assistant U.S. Attorney initially sent a request for a written staff opinion to the Florida Bar, which is referenced in the September 29 email chain.

keyFacts: An Assistant U.S. Attorney from West Palm Beach is seeking a written staff opinion from the Florida Bar's ethics counsel in September 2008.
The request includes attachments related to victim notification procedures, suggesting it may be connected to the Epstein case or similar prosecution.
Elizabeth Clark Tarbert, as ethics counsel, indicates that most inquiries receive a reply within 3-5 weeks.
The document shows coordination between federal prosecutors and state bar ethics officials on procedural matters.
